lines.text: You never say please. You never say thank you.
Please don't be an idiot. Thank you.
You have the right to remain silent; although personally, I don't feel remaining silent's all it's cracked up to be... Smoke?
Don't you even wonder why?
Why what?
Why he lied.
I'm a homicide detective. The only time I wonder why is when they tell me the truth.

Sometimes I wanna call my wife just to hear the sound of her voice. But I know that five minutes into that phone call, my blood pressure is going through the roof, the phone is sailing across the room and I'm wishing that she's on a plane falling out of the sky. It's over. I know it's over. But I had to replace six telephones before I, I really got the hint.
You still believe that my cousin killed that boy because he was an Arab?
Hikmet was not an Arab. Turks are not Arabs...
My cousin could not consciously kill someone.

I don't think it was premeditated. I think it was inherent. Jim's racism is so much a part of him, that he didn't have a chance to think about what he was doing. Jim is worse than a Klansman. 'Cause at least in their white sheets, they are recognizable. Your cousin's brand of bigotry is much more frightening because, like still water, it runs deep. He doesn't even see it himself.
You're wrong, dead wrong.

The only one "dead wrong" is Hikmet Gersel. Did you see what happened when the verdict was announced? They applauded. Those law-abiding citizens, those good people applauded the death of a child. Let me ask you something, Tim - and then you tell me whether or not it was racially motivated - if that boy had been American, if that boy had been white - do you think anyone would have cheered?
[over a dead body]
Another drug dealer. Collect all thirteen in the series, win a set of dishes.
Live stupid, die young.
He who loses control, loses.
our day begins when yours ends.
It's hard to meet single woman on this job. You meet plenty of widows, but the timing just don't seem right.
Homicide, sweet homicide.
Life would be perfect, if it was just kids and dogs.
I just want you to know that I'm here for you. And if you want a hug, I'd be happy to give you one.
A hug?
Yeah.
Do you and Lewis hug?
Yeah.
A lot?
No, not a lot.
But enough.
What do you mean?
Well, do you want Lewis to hug you more?
Forget I brought this all up.
No, no, no, no. *You* brought up the hugging thing.
You know, sometimes you're funny. Then there's now.

[looking at corpse]
With those beady eye and that mustache he looks like a cross between Steve Buscemi, John Waters and Edgar Allen Poe.
Aren't they all the same person?
It's better to be judged by twelve than carried by six.
Lemme tell you one thing, all right? You gotta do everything I say.
Well, there's nothing I won't do; but some things are gonna cost you extra.

You know, every day I get out of bed and drag myself to the next cup of coffee. I take a sip and the caffeine kicks in. I can focus my eyes again. My brain starts to order the day. I'm up, I'm alive. I'm ready to rock. But the time is coming when I wake up and decide that I'm not getting out of bed. Not for coffee, or food or sex. If it comes to me, fine. If it won't, fine. No more expectations. The longer I live, the less I know. I should know more. I should know the coffee's killing me. You're suspicious of your suspicions? I'm jealous, Kay; I'm so jealous. You still have the heart to have doubts. Me? I'm going to lock up a 14-year-old kid for what could be the rest of his natural life. I got to do this. This is my job. This is the deal. This is the law. This is my day. I have no doubts or suspicions about it. Heart has nothing to do with it any more. It's all in the caffeine.
I'm a detective, Frank. I'm a keen observer of the human condition. I pick up on the subtlest clues, I react to the slightest suggestion. In short, I deduct.
Who told you?
Brodie.

I can't stop seeing her face. Adena Watson's face in the rain. Wounds on her body. She was so tiny. I try not to care, but if I do that, if I actually stop caring, then I stop being who I am. No job's worth that.
You know, I was thinking of printing up one of those bikini calendars. You know, the cops of Baltimore type thing.
What happened?
You seen the cops in Baltimore?
You're right. Munch in a thong would be a little hard on the eyes.
Do you think some people work harder to be stupider than others?
I'm going to go out on a limb and say yes.
[At the scene of a priest's murder]
Heaven can wait. Homicide can't.
When in Rome, do as the Romans do. When in Baltimore, do as I tell you to.
The Italians are an unforgiving lot.
I know, but we make great pasta. It balances out.
[Bolander, the primary investigator into the suicide of Detective Steve Crosetti, is being pressured to rule it a murder]

Is that what you're asking, Lieutenant? To make it a murder? A murder with no murderer? A murder that can't be solved? If you order me to do it, I'll do it. Hell, my clearance rate is so low these days one more open murder isn't going to make much difference. Everyone says 'Do it for Steve', and I keep thinking that if he chose to commit suicide, what right to I have - what right does ANY of us have - to make that go away? I don't agree with what he did, but if that was his final statement, should I wipe that clear just for our peace of mind? I mean, nobody wants to admit it, but everyone knows what happened.
Fourteen years old... When I was fourteen, jeez, I was in the ninth grade, and I don't remember much of what I was doing, but I know I was nowhere close to picking up a gun and shooting another kid.
How old should our shooter be?
Not fourteen.
So if he's what, fifteen, sixteen years old, it makes any more sense?
No.
How old should he be then? What's the cut off age? Seventeen? Eighteen?
I don't know, but not fourteen.

When you find out, clue me in, awright? I'd like to know when any of this killing, at any age, from six to sixty, makes any sense. One time I want to hear about a murder that makes sense. Just one time. For any reason.
Meldrick! In the mood for a multiple homicide?
On a Friday night? Always.
Baltimore, home of the misdemeanor homicide.
There's no absolutes in life; only in vodka.
[Crosetti and Lewis are in adjacent stalls in the men's room]
Got any toilet paper?
Nope.
Got five ones for a five?
[answering the phone at Christmas]
Ho-ho-homicide.
You sure you want me with you?
Yeah, sure, why not?
I don't know, uh, last time we worked together you were kind of snarky.
Snarky?
Yeah, snarky, you know, from the ancient Greek, meaning butt head.
If you were going to hide a body, where would you bury it?
In a cemetery.

Kay might die. I'm not gonna close my eyes and pretend that nothing bad's gonna happen. Because you know what? It already did. So you gotta tell me, what're you supposed to do when your partner dies on you?
What you do is... You keep going.
What do you mean, you keep going?

You get up, you do your job, you make it through every day... And you hope that one day you're gonna wake up and it won't hurt so much. Then the next day it will hurt a little less, and the next day, even less than that. It's not like you forget them, you know? Your life is changed forever. It's not ever gonna go back to the way it was... But you get through it... You just keep going on.
That's it? Keep going?
That's it.
Meldrick, that's the stupidest thing I ever heard.
You're spitting on my advice. You call me down here, I open my heart to you, and now you're spiting on what I got to say.
Basically, yeah.
Gimme back the giraffe.
What? Forget it.
You don't like my advice, you ain't getting the giraffe.
It's "till death do you part." You die, you part.

Say Baltimore, and I'll tell you within ten blocks where you were born. Yeah, you from here. You got that home grown look. The not-too-southern, not-too-northern, not on the ocean but still on the water look. With maybe a touch of inbreeding.
Luther, Luther. Look both ways when you cross the street, my brother.
You do the same.
The only thing I have in common with Judaism is we both don't like to work on Saturdays.
Blind faith is the crutch of fools.
I don't like to form attachments with people. They either get suspended or throw china at you.

[Bayliss is taking some pills for his back pain]
What d'ya got there, Timmy? Some good stuff, huh? Percodan, Percocet, Tylenol, greenies?
They're muscle relaxants!
Even better.
You don't get any!
No-one's willing to share their drugs anymore.
So you admit you deal drugs?
In today's economy? You bet!
[looking over a dead body]
From the tracks on his arms, large caliber wound, proximity to a heroin market... I'd say it was a heated dispute about the symbolism of red and blue in 18th-century French romantic poetry.
[Bolander sees bird droppings on his car]
Would you look at this? Pigeons!
Not from a pigeon, it's from a waterfowl.
A what?
A waterfowl. From a mallard.
A duck?
A well-fed duck.
Right, like you can tell the difference. That couldn't come from a seagull, I suppose?
No, gulls have a milky white splurter. Notice the lobular pattern, these splays within splays.
Munch... why do you know these things?
[Pembleton needs the clothes of a brain-dead child for evidence]
I need you to give me these clothes.
I can't.
You have to!

I *have* to? Let me tell you what I *have* to do today, okay? I have to go in there and I have to watch the doctors pinch Patrick's legs. I have to watch them stick pins at the bottoms of his feet. I have to watch them pour cold water, first in his right ear, then in his left, to see if his eyes moved today. And I have to hear them tell me that they don't. His eyes don't. I hear them say this. Nothing else can be done. And this is just a little *boy*! And they have to say this about him? *You* have to have his clothes? *You* have to know what we saw yesterday? I have to remember... Patrick standing there, he *has* to see the dinosaurs! He *has* to go to that window! It's always "one more minute!" He *always* has to do what he wants! And then he falls down and I think he's just teasing and he's going to get up in a minute and I'm going to yell at him to just get up and not get dirty! I *want* to see him get up... from his *own* bed. Do I have to think that he can lay there like this for another 50 or 60 years? Do I have to think that this is what he wants? Why do I have to? Why do I think that it can't be Patrick in there?
Life should come with a money back guarantee. If you're not satisfied, return unused portion for a full refund.
Every evening is as random as the next, death doesn't follow a schedule.
Have you been smoking the dope in the evidence room again?

You're saving your really good lies for some smarter cop, is that it? I'm just a donut in the on-deck circle. Wait until the real guy gets here. Wait until that big guy comes back. I'm probably just his secretary. I'm just Montel Williams. You want to talk to Larry King.
I'm telling you the truth.

I've been in murder police for ten years. If you're going to lie to me, you lie to me with respect. What is it? Is it my shoes? Is it my haircut? Got a problem with my haircut? Don't you ever lie to me like I'm Montel Williams. I am not Montel Williams. I am not Montel Williams.
Who's Montel Williams?
I'm not Montel Williams.
You're a man.
I'm your partner.
I'm a woman.
You're a cop.
Virtue isn't virtue unless it slams up against vice. So consequently, your virtue's not real virtue. Until it's been tested... tempted.
But what if they make me take a test? I can't take tests. I always clutch. What if I take it and fail and all our dreams come crashing down?
Well, then it's simple. Meldrick and I will harm you.

Oh, I get it. You don't feel anything at all. You're the type of guy that two weeks from now, you'll be stopped at a traffic light and all this will hit you and when it hits, it'll hit hard. It'll hit you so hard that your heart will burst into a hundred pieces.
Either it's murder, or this library has a very strict overdue policy.
How come every time I open that refrigerator, there's one drop of milk left in the carton? So who has to go to the 7-11 and replace the carton of milk?
Me.
That's besides the point. He's doing that on my behalf. He could be doing something else for me.
Name one miracle that's happened in your lifetime.
How 'bout the fact that I haven't killed you yet?
You go when you're supposed to go, and everything else is homicide.
You're not Catholic and you took communion?
Yeah, is that wrong?
If my God wins... You're screwed.

What I have is, I have a second in time. I have a split second in an abandoned building with a gun in my hand and every instinct is telling me who I am at that moment. That's what I got left and that's all I got left... and I'm a homicide cop.
What is y'all's fascination with sperm?
It's just a healthy curiosity. If it weren't for our daddy's sperm, wouldn't none of us be here.
Or your mama's eggs.
So does the violence make them stupid or does the stupidity lead to violence?
Well, that's chicken and egg semantics. The important point is that we win some cases because our brains are repositories for intelligence and their brains are day-old banana pudding.
In this job you gotta be able to howl at yourself, or else you die inside.
Let me tell you what happened to me last night.
Is this about sex?
No.
Forget it.
I'm lying in bed...
Ooh, what were you wearing?

I'm tired of being the only one around here who gives a damn. You're looking at the new Frank Pembleton. Budding Republican and practicing selfish bastard. Savior of no one but himself. Shot of Gold Natty Bo. This is the new me.

I've been a cop for a long time. And drugs out there, we're never gonna win that. There's a hundred open-air drug markets in this city and fifty thousand drug fiends out there. And we are taking on human desires with lawyers, and jailhouses, and lockups, and you and I both know human desire is kicking us in the ass.

We're talking about sacred freedoms here - notably, your Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination. Hey, if it was good enough for Ollie North and Mark Furhman, who the hell are you to incriminate yourself at the first opportunity?
[Detective John Munch has shown up unexpectedly at Detective Stanley Bolander's double-date]
Every fairy-tale has a nightmare, and this is mine.
Meldrick, Crosetti's dead. He can't have any secrets any more.
I'm not really a waitress. I write. One-acts.
Hunh, one-act plays.
Read them and we'll talk about them, okay?
You're a writer and you had to ask me for a pen?
My life is total irony.
All in one act, huh?
You said summer was hell.
Well... it was.
It's all mind over matter, Bayliss.
No, no, it's more than mind over matter. I know my mind and my mind remembers my ass melting into the tops of my shoes, all right? Summer was hell.
There's no humidity in hell.
What, you do a field report?
By all reliable accounts, there's not a single drop of water to pass between heaven and hell. Hell is a dry heat.
Oh. Well, book me a flight.

[on pulling a quadruple shift]
I am soooo damn tired! My eyes are so far back of my head, I think I'm seeing things from a thousand years away.

[punchline to a joke Lewis tells in episodes broadcast nearly two years apart]
... so the bear says, "You didn't really come here to hunt, did you?"

[coming out of a bar and then saluting an American flag]
I'm too damn sober.
[Lewis and Kellerman drove up to Hazel, Pennsylvania to bring a female suspect back to Baltimore]
You guys from Baltimore, here to pick up Rose Halligan?
That's correct. I'm Detective Lewis, this is...
Uh, you can't have her.
What do you mean?
Regulations stipulate a policewoman escorts a female prisoner.

[gesturing to Kellerman]
Meet Detective Michelle Kellerman.
You're not a woman.
I used to be.

[upon learning that having Crosetti's favourite pastries at his funeral would cost $200]
That silly man and his silly cookies.
Do be a milk drinker. Don't be a crack addict.
Well, you're a girl. A woman. A woman. A woman with wild red hair. I can't stay with you.
What are you afraid of? I'm going to chain you to the bedpost and cover you with butter?
Only thing is, I know that you won't.

I watch my weight. I watch my diet. I watch my blood pressure. Every eight hours, no matter where I am, or what I'm doing, I hafta take a little white pill. If I don't follow the rules, I die. I'm not going to treat you differently. I won't. 'Cause that's not who I am. And who I am is all I have left.
Remember kids, don't just say no to drugs, say "No, thank you".
[regarding an uncooperative witness]
We're gonna neutron this little bastard!
[on the engine that Detective Meldrick Lewis has bought for the car he is building]

Let me tell you, that doesn't play with me. See, when you buy a house, you don't buy a pile of dirt with a toilet on top. You get four walls which constitute a dwelling. You, if you look closely, have squat here.
You're Mrs. Nawls, Darryl's mother?
I'm his mother.
[she reads their faces and begins to panic]
Where's Darryl? Is he in trouble? Is he okay? Has he been in an accident or something?
Mrs. Nawls, I'm a homicide detective.
I took the liberty of having my craw removed years ago so that I could sleep at night.
Don't nobody know nothing 'bout no shooting at no cops?
[working a murder case since the squad is shorthanded]
My first job as a foot soldier in I don't know how many years, and it's a stone-cold whodunit.
